title: Are humans naturally aggressive and violent? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes, humans are inherently violent, as manifested in those situations that trigger our "lizard brain" reactions.  Aggression, territory defense, dominance competition, all this primitive survival strategies that you can observe in alligators e.g. are hardwired in prehistoric parts also of our human brain. There is no exception. Usually we are not aware of them them because the mother nature equipped us with with more advanced computational modules (limbic system+neocortex) throughout the evolution. And usually it is these newer modules that are in control. But not always. Take from man his property, job, hurt his family, pride, isolate him socially ...and beast is out. Weaken his neocortex control mechanism with alcohol and disaster is not far away. For sure humans are not violent always. If our major needs are fulfilled and we live in a mature social environment interactively then other survival mechanisms prevail. But let's not make a mistake. Roots of violence are always there inside of us. They are in stand by mode, waiting for an event.

Maybe. There are a few genes that are shown to influence aggression in people. One is MAOA. A gene that is found to correlate with aggression. Furthermore, there is also evidence for a biological disposition in the womb. There is also shown to be reduced activity in the Pre-Frontal Cortex in the brains of some violent offenders (however this isn't always the case). There are other genes that have been shown to affect violent behaviour.      But here is the catch, not everyone who has these biological markers is violent.  So there is an element of environmental conditions that can mediate the genetic make up. For instance research indicates those with more resources have a greater ability at mediating their behaviour and tend to be able to better plan ahead. This is an ability that is found in the Pre-Frontal Cortex, and may grow faster in better resourced environments.  . I'd say we are inherently violent. As a society we quite frequently of schizophrenic views on violence. There is plenty of media that is violent, video games are violent, films are violent. In fact films that have high sexual content in them are often rated higher than those with violence. Our society doesn't have a big problem with violence as it likes to think. It just has a problem with violence towards the group of the individual observing it. I don't think people like accepting biological aspects of violence because they like the dualism of good vs. evil.  Sources to Look Up: Raine, A. (2013) Anatomy of Violence: The Biological Roots of Violence Type in James Fallon and Psychopath into YouTube (or for that matter Adrian Raine).  Also, for more information on Psychopaths see Robert Hare (some of his research found Psychopath brains function on a lower wave length then others).

Violence is easier to notice and gets more attention than peace, hence why there seems to be so much of the former compared to the latter. You are not disillusioned about the human race. You are disillusioned by a false perception of it. Are we "naturally" aggressive and violent? Based on your description, you clearly don't mean that we're biologically hardwired that way, otherwise there would be no peaceful people. You may be using it to ask whether or not we have that kind of an inclination. We don't, otherwise there would be no counter-cultural movements that resist the violence of established traditions and establish more peaceful alternatives. If aggression and violence are so natural, how do you explain post traumatic stress disorder. Soldiers who were trained to kill when commanded get that. Those that kill without remorse represent a teeny tiny fraction of the human population. If it's so natural, then why do central governments have to brainwash people with widespread propaganda campaigns that demonizes other people? Picture this. Suppose you had the opportunity to kill someone. Would you do it? You are against killing, so why would you? Why do you pretend that you aren't human (something more) so that you can judge us all from your moral high ground? The fact that you are human and have the capacity to be against abhorrent behaviour should suggest that others can too if they had the means and motives to develop and express that capacity.

No, most things a human does is the result of prior experience and actions. If you were to bring up a child to adulthood without exposing him/her to any sort of violence in any way, that child would have no notion of what violence is. I can't say whether that would be good or bad thing(most likely not good). The first time they see violence they might not know how to interpret it. Although humans are very clever and can easily connect dots, so unless you take away all the ways that human could figure out that violence is wrong, they really would be dumbfounded.  EDIT: I've been thinking about it, and my answer above might not be entirely true. Humans historically have had to fight in various situations to survive. Those that did fight were more likely to survive than those who did not. Thus evolution will favour those who are more likely to do violence. There may be an embedded system in the human brain that promotes violence to increase likelihood of survival.

Of course we are. Violence frequently happens, and the fact that we are capable of it depends on our being equipped by nature to produce it. We have the teeth and claws and muscles of a carnivore and have always made our living by killing other animals and eating them. We augmented our fairly mediocre carnivore equipment with weapons and strategies that our big brains created for us. We then made use of these tools and dispositions toward violence in conflict situations with others of our own kind. All this is completely consistent with our nature. However, we also are by nature a species of cooperative individuals. We can get more done in groups than as solitary individuals or families. These useful arrangements give us incentives to not be violent with each other, or to at least keep it within bounds. In addition, as the tools by which individuals can do violence to others have grown more powerful and easier to use in many ways, we may get to something like the peace that came from mutual assured destruction between the US and the USSR. If even the least of us can bring significant violence to bear if he or she feels sufficiently mistreated, we may wind up having to treat each other well despite our dispositions to violently seize whatever we want.

Of course we are. We evolved in a natural environment where we were more likely to be prey than predator. We would have disappeared as a species before we climbed down from the trees had we not possessed the capability to fight for our lives and those of our kind. That capability remains one of the most basic keys to our nature. But we are also social creatures with a capacity for empathy. Those three characteristics are expressed in different measure in each of us. But they exist in all of us, save for a tiny fraction at each end of the bell curve.

Some studies have suggested a link between group violence to overpopulation that results in an excess of adolescent males. Having nothing better to do they form gangs and engage in aggressive play which can escalate into violence. This behavior is characteristic of societies that have a surplus of resources — otherwise the young men would be busy in food procurement activities. Are humans naturally aggressive? No. It is a systemic phenomenon which can be amplified in various cultural situations. Aggressive and violent behavior is usually something men get over as they mature.

There isn’t much evidence against humans, on some level, not being violent. It is unfortunately required for survival. In order to hunt and eat, we must kill. In order to clear the land for farming, we must destroy the forest and competing plant life so we can use the land for crops. In order to domesticate livestock, we must employ violent tactics to ‘break’ the animals and to prevent the natural predators from taking from the herd. We must also protect our food supply from those other humans who would take it from us. Daniel Quinn attempts to analyze this in his book “Ishmael” where the advent of surplus agriculture began a series of events that changed humans forever. Howard Bloom takes a much deeper look into the violence of humanity in his book “The Lucifer Principle: A Scientific Expedition into the Forces of History”. Here he analyzes trends that humans share in common with many creatures in the animal kingdom, and even trends regarding single celled life. From the pecking order of chickens as applied to human sociology to the propensity for humans to band together under the umbrella of a central set of ideas which Bloom calls a ‘meme’ in order to feel safe in their convictions that any other set of ideas come from non-human or sub-human creatures that only look similar, but are in some way stained with impurity. This is a major theme of many religions: convert and be cleansed of your profane ways and you can become a true human. Yet, even inside of such religions there is often dissent among different schools of interpretation that leads to various levels of violence, from finger pointing and shouting to protests and at times in history outright violence. To put it another way, humans would not be able to survive without violence simply because life feeds on life. We must take life in order to sustain life, be it plant or animal or our fellow humans. Does that make us intrinsically violent as a species, or does that just leave us with a need to be aware, accountable, and responsible for the role in the world we play and tame the ‘violence’ needed to survive and direct it toward other avenues of release instead of just restlessly destroying each other and everything we see?
